title.narrative: NUTRITION OP 2 QUALITY SUPPLY SERVICES

description.narrative: By 2023, under-five children, adolescents and pregnant women have access to improved nutrition quality services at key delivery points, including in times of emergency, which contributes to Early Detection And Treatment Of Malnutrition, Nutrition In Early Childhood, Nutrition Of Adolescents And Women. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Fostering Innovation And Use Of New Technologies, Operational Support To Programme Delivery, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building, Systems Strengthening To Leave No One Behind. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2023, Government has the capacity at national and decentralized level to improve policy, planning, monitoring, coordination and resource leveraging of Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene (WASH) programme for equitable and sustainable access to climate resilient Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene (WASH) services at scale

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: By 2023, under-five children, adolescents and pregnant women have access to improved nutrition quality services at key deliverypoints, including in times of emergency

description.narrative: UNICEF supported the response to the severe drought emergency in Southern Madagascar targeting 110,000 children with severe wasting. Through this support 91% of the 59,784 children treated for severe wasting recovered. Humanitarian-development nexus was also prioritized, informed by the operational Roadmap for the UN Global Action Plan on Child Wasting. 25% of the nutrition supply chain strengthening road map was completed and 100% (279) of health clinics in affected districts were equipped with capacity-building, information systems and operational supports to provide nutrition services. At community level 106,387 families (15%) were trained and equipped for self-detection of children with acute malnutrition. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:10/01/2022
